metadata.title: Nano-Au@PANI core-shell nanoparticles via in-situ polymerization as electrode for supercapacitor

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Nano-Au@PANI core-shell nanoparticles via in-situ polymerization as electrode for supercapacitor
Yongtao Tan, Yafei Zhang, Lingbin Kong, Long Kang, Fen Ran
PII: S0925-8388(17)32055-8 DOI: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2017.06.068 Reference: JALCOM 42136
To appear in: Journal of Alloys and Compounds
Received Date: 30 March 2017 Revised Date: 4 June 2017 Accepted Date: 5 June 2017
Please cite this article as: Y. Tan, Y. Zhang, L. Kong, L. Kang, F. Ran, Nano-Au@PANI coreshell nanoparticles via in-situ polymerization as electrode for supercapacitor, Journal of Alloys and Compounds (2017), doi: 10.1016/j.jallcom.2017.06.068.
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

sections.heading: Polymerization as Electrode for Supercapacitor
sections.text: Yongtao Tan, Yafei Zhang, Lingbin Kong, Long Kang, Fen Ran*

sections.heading: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Processing and Recycling of Non-ferrous Metals,
sections.text:
Lanzhou University of Technology, Lanzhou 730050, P. R. China *Corresponding author: Fen Ran (ranfen@163.com; or ranfen@lut.cn)
Abstract: With the aim of improving conductivity and shortening diffusion length,
the conductive polymer polyaniline shell was grown on the surface of gold
nanoparticles via in-situ polymerization, as confirmed by transmission electron
microscopy, fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analyses.
The core-shell nano-Au@PANI with an average diameter of 22.17 nm as well as the
nano-Au with an average diameter of 18.52 nm was prepared. Electrochemical
investigation by using CHI660E workstation exhibits that the prepared material has
good electrochemical performance and the highest specific capacitance is up to 285.0 F g-1, far higher than that of the pristine PANI, 115.0 F g-1; after 4000 cycles,
nano-Au@PANI displays better cycle stability compare with that of pristine PANI.
Furthermore, nano-Au@PANI are combined with AC to fabricate the hybrid
supercapacitor of nano-Au@PANI//AC, which shows a maximum energy density of 7.01 W h kg-1 with the power density of 260 W kg-1; and the maximum power density of 4.2 kW kg-1 and energy density of 1.74 W h kg-1.
Keywords: Au Nanoparticles; Conductive Polymer; Supercapacitor
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the consume of fossil fuels and the change of climate, the renewable energy
resources, for instance, sun energy and wind, are guided as advanced trend and energy
storage system, as service for energy, also is paid more attention because the energy
released in its time of need. Electrochemical capacitors, also called
ultrasupercapacitors or supercapacitors, as a new energy storage device, are applied in
most fields such as portable electronics, hybrid electric vehicles, and so on, due to its
good electrochemical performance of fast charging/discharging speed, high power
density, and long cycle stability [1,2]. Electrochemical capacitors can be divided two
main categories: electronic double layer capacitors (EDLC) and pseudocapacitors.
EDLC stores energy directly as charge at the surface of electrode/electrolyte, while
pseudocapacitors stores energy from faradaic reaction, involving the transfer of
charge across the interface between electrode and electrolyte.
In general, electrochemical capacitors is similar with battery which contains electrode
materials, electrolyte, separator, and other parts. Among these, the electrode materials
play very important role and have decisive effect. Carbon materials [3-7], such as
carbon tubes [8], porous carbon [9, 10], mesoporous carbon [11], biomass carbon [12],
graphite [13], are applied in supercapacitors on the basis of EDLCs storage
mechanism. Pseudocapacitors electrode materials mainly includes metal oxides, such
as MnO2 [14, 15], NiO [16], Co3O4 [17], and so on, metal nitride [18-20], such as VN, TiN, and so on, and conducive polymers [21], such as polyaniline [22], polypyrrole
[23], and so on. Polyaniline (PANI) is becoming a focus point material owing to its
synthesis ease, environment friendly, and low cost. However, pseudocapacitor
electrode material involving PANI always suffers from low conductivity and not good
cycle stability.
Gold is a type of high conducive material and gold nanoparticles (nano-Au) structure
is easy to control, which has been applied widely in catalyst and biology field.
Specially, Au/PANI nanocomposites could combine the advantages of each
complement, and further obtain excellent performances of nanocomposites [24, 25].
Wang et al prepared dandelion-like Au/PANI nanocomposites via a simple one-step
process without any additives or templates for application as SERS nanosensors [26].
Xing et al reported a core-shell structure of conductive polymer shell on gold
nanoparticles and nanochains with different shell thickness [27]. Wael H. Eisa et al
synthesized water-soluble gold/polyaniline core-shell nanocomposite and proposed
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
the formation mechnism of Au/PANI core-shell nanocomposites [28]. Lang et al
reported three-dimensional bicontinuous nanoporous Au/PANI composite films made
by one-step electrochemical polymerization of PANI shell onto dealloyed nanoporous
gold skeletons for the applications in electrochemical supercapacitors, which
exhibited excellent electrochemical performances of ultrahigh volumetric capacitance (∼1500 F cm-3), and energy density (∼0.078 W h cm-3) [29].
In this paper, we prepared a nano-Au@PANI core-shell nanocomposite via in-situ
polymerization method on nano-Au surface and applied it as the electrode material for
supercapacitor. This high conductivity of the nano-metal core combined the thin shell
of nano-PANI layer could make high-efficient use of the active material and high
electron density to shorten the length of diffusion. Based on these, the
nano-Au@PANI core shell would show good electrochemical performance compared
to the pristine PANI electrode material, providing a strategy to synthesize
supercapacitor electrode material.

sections.heading: 2.1 Chemicals
sections.text:
Aniline monomer (ANI) was distilled prior to use. Hydrogen tetrachloroaurate
hydrate (HAuCl4·3H2O), sodium citrate (Na3C6H5O7·2H2O), ammonium peroxydisulfate ((NH4)2S2O8, APS), sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), and H2SO4 were used as received.

sections.heading: 2.2 Fabrication of Au Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Au nanoparticles (nano-Au) were synthseized using the method reported previously
[30, 31]. A solution of 100 mL H2O and 10 mg HAuCl4 (4 mg/mL) was heated to boiling under strong stirring; thereafter, 3 mL of sodium citrate solution (1 wt.%) was
injected into the three-neck flask. The reaction mixture was refluxed for half an hour.
Nano-Au solution was collected by centrifuging at 12 000 rpm for 10 min.

sections.heading: 2.3 Synthesis of Core-Shell nano-Au@PANI
sections.text:
The core-shell nanoparticles of nano-Au@PANI were fabricated referring to literature
[27], which was modified as follows: 4 mL as-prepared nano-Au solution was
concentrated to ca. 30 µL by centrifugation at 12000 rpm for 10 min; the upper
colorless solution was removed, and then the concentrated nano-Au solution was
added into the mixture involving 1.5 mL aniline solution (10 mM) and 0.3 mL SDS
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
(40 mM). After the mixture being shaken for about 10 s, another 1.5 mL acidic
solution of APS (10 mM) and H2SO4 (0.5 M) was added, which was incubated for 12~24 h at room temperature after shake for 10 s. The product of nano-Au@PANI
was collected by centrifuging the reaction solution at 12 000 rpm for 10 min, washed
by distilled water for at least three times, and dried at 80 °C for 12 h.

sections.heading: 2.4 Materials Characterization
sections.text:
The morphologies were examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM,
JEOL2010). The chemical structure was confirmed using fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) in the range of 400~4000 cm-1 and the thermogravimetric
analyses (TGA) was performed by heating the samples from 25 to 900 °C. The TGA measurement was conducted under N2 atmosphere at a flow rate of 50 mL min −1 and a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption experiments
(Micromeritics, ASAP 2010M, USA). The surface area was calculated using the
Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. Pore-size distributions were calculated by
the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method using the desorption branch of the
isotherm. Electrical conductivity was determined using a four point probe (RTS-9).

sections.heading: 2.5.1 Electrode Preparation
sections.text:
Active material, conducting graphite, acetylene black, and poly tetrafluoroethylene
according to the mass ratio of 80: 7.5: 7.5: 5 (wt.%) were mixed in an agate mortar, which was coated on the stainless of geometric surface area of ca. 1 cm2 as current
collector and pressed at 10 M Pa for ca. 15 s. Finally, the electrode was dried at 80 °C
for 12 h.

sections.heading: 2.5.2 Electrochemical Performances
sections.text:
Three-electrode system, including the as-prepared active material as work electrode, a
platinum foil electrode as counter electrode, and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE)
as reference electrode, respectively, was employed. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and
galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) measurements were conducted in 1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed over a frequency in a range of 0.01~105 Hz at an amplitude 5 mV. All the
electrochemical experiments were carried out using CHI660E work station at 20 ±
1 °C.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Specific capacitance (SC) was calculated from GCD curve according to equation:
Cs = I∆t / m∆V (1)
Where Cs is specific capacitance (F g -1), I is discharge current (A), ∆t is discharge time (s), m is active material mass, and ∆V is potential window.

sections.heading: 2.6 Preparation of the Supercapacitor Device
sections.text:
The asymmetric supercapacitor included two electrodes: positive electrode involving
core-shell nano-Au@PANI and activated carbon (AC) material as negative electrode, respectively; each electrode has a geometric surface area of 1 cm2. For the
supercapacitor, the charge balance follows the relationship:
Q+ = Q- (2)
Where Q represents the charge stored, + and – represents positive electrode and
negative electrode respectively.
Q = Cm * m * E (3)
Where Cm means specific capacitance, m represents total mass of two electrodes, and E is the potential window of charge/discharge tests.
According to above equation (2) and (3),
m+ / m-= Cm- / Cm+ * ∆V- / ∆V+ (4)
The SC of active carbon and Au@PANI exhibited 220.0 F g-1 and 285.0 F g-1,
respectively. The optimal mass ratio should be m- / m+ = 1.62 in the asymmetric supercapacitor. Electrochemical measurements of the asymmetric supercapacitor were
carried out using an electrochemical workstation as mentioned above.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC
CE
PT ED

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The synthesis diagram of core-shell nano-Au@PANI is shown in Figure 1a. The
solution involving aniline, SDS, and nano-Au was prepared before adding APS
aqueous solution. In this system, aniline was firstly adsorbed on the surface of
nano-Au due to the electrostatic interactions existed between aniline molecule and
nano-Au; then SDS molecule enclosed aniline monomer on the surface of the
nanoparticles, playing the role of physical isolation to prevent agglomeration of
nanoparticles. After adding the APS solution and H2SO4, polymerization of aniline was conducted and grown on the surface of nano-Au at room temperature by APS as
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC
CE
PT
ED
oxidation agent, together with doping action by H2SO4. The core-shell nano-Au@PANI was obtained and collected by centrifugation. The as-prepared
sample of nano-Au and nano-Au@PANI were characterized by TEM, and the images
are shown in Figure 1b and c. It can be seen that Au nanoparticles have good
spherical shape and smooth spherical edge. After coated with PANI, nano-Au@PANI
remained the same spherical shape, and the surface PANI shell on nano-Au@PANI
can also be found because of the different electron density between nano-Au and
PANI. Particle size distribution histogram of nano-Au and nano-Au@PANI are shown
in Figure 1d and e, respectively. The diameter distribution of nano-Au were mainly
16~19 nm, while nano-Au@PANI exhibited the diameter of 21~24 nm. And the
average diameter of nano-Au and nano-Au@PANI were 18.52 and 22.17 nm,
respectively. In addition, the average thickness of PANI shell on nano-Au@PANI was
calculated to be 1.83 nm. Based on these data, we concluded that the core-shell
nanoparticle of nano-Au@PANI with uniform size and ultrathin coating of conducting
polymer was successfully fabricated by the facile method.
Figure 2 FTIR spectrum of the pristine PANI and nano-Au@PANI
Nano-Au@PANI was characterized by FTIR, and the results are shown Figure 2. The broad peak at ~3420 cm-1 was assigned to -OH group，the peaks of ~2920 and ~2850 cm−1 could be explained as asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of the -CH band. The curve of pristine PANI showed a peak at 1560 cm-1, which was assigned to ring C-C stretching in the semiquinonoid (SQ) and the peak at 1480 cm-1 was due to B ring C-C stretching in NH-B-NH units (“B-band”) [32]. In addition, ~1295 cm-1, ~1238 cm-1 and ~1130 cm-1 were the typical peaks implying the pristine PANI of
conducting form [32, 33]. In the curve of nano-Au@PANI, the characterized peak of ~1630 cm-1 was related to C=N vibrational stretching mode for the quinonoid units; and the peak at 1403 cm-1 was ascribed to C-H scissoring vibrations [28]. The peak at
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
~1175 cm-1 can be assigned to the C-H in-plane deformation vibration of B rings, mixed with the contribution of asymmetric SO3 stretching in HSO4 - [32]; other peaks of ~1470 cm-1 and ~1290 cm-1 occurred a little offset compared to pristine PANI. On
the whole, the spectrum of nano-Au@PANI was similar to that of pristine PANI. That
is to say, the conducting polymer of PANI grown on the surface of gold nanoparticles
almost has the same molecular structure as that of the pristine PANI.
Figure 3 TGA analysis of the pristine PANI and nano-Au@PANI
The composition of the core-shell nano-Au@PANI was further analyzed by TGA method, and the spectra of nano-Au@PANI and pristine PANI were measured in N2 atmosphere from room temperature to 900 °C, which are shown in Figure 3. From the figure one can see that the mass of nano-Au@PANI decreased gradually and remained 31.08 % residual, higher than that of the pristine PANI, 30.09 %. According to the difference, the PANI content in nano-Au@PANI was calculated to be 98.56 %. In order to further investigate the electrochemical performance, the nano-Au@PANIs were prepared with different polymerization time. Figure 4 shows the electrochemical performance of core-shell nano-Au@PANI-12, nano-Au@PANI-16, and nano-Au@PANI-24, prepared at the reaction time of 12 h, 16 h, and 24 h, respectively. The all CV curves exhibited one couple strong redox peaks and another couple weak redox peak (Figure 4a). The strong peaks were owing to the redox transition of the PANI between a semiconducting state (leucoemeraldine form) and a conducting state (polaronic emeraldine form), and the weak peaks were attributed to the emeraldine-pernigraniline transformation [34, 35]. The area inside the CV curve reflects the specific capacitance. It is clearly the area inside the CV curve of nano-Au@PANI were larger than that of pristine PANI. Figure 4b displays the GCD curves. The relationship between potential and time was non-linear implied the PANI
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
electrode materials based on the faradaic pseudocapacitance. The specific capacitances (SC) according to the equation (1) from the GCD curves were calculated and the SC data is showed in Figure 4c. The specific capacitance of nano-Au@PANIs increased and then decreased with the increase of polymerization time, and a maximum value of 278 F g-1 at the current density of 1 A g-1, far higher than that of pristine PANI, 115 F g-1 at the same current density. The enhancement of specific capacitance with the reaction time increasing due to the rational thickness of PANI in the surface of nano-Au@PANI for electrochemical process. In general, this ideal thickness for EDLC is 0.5~1 nm [36]. Figure 4d represents the SC tested at different current density. At the same current density, the specific capacitances of all nano-Au@PANIs were higher and the downward slopes of the curves were milder than that of pristine PANI. When the current density increased from 0.5 to 5 A g-1, the specific capacitance retentions were 58.6, 87.7, 85.5, and 79.7 % for pristine PANI, nano-Au@PANI-12, nano-Au@PANI-16, and nano-Au@PANI-24, respectively. The highest SC for nano-Au@PANI at 0.5 A g-1 was up to 285 F g-1, comparable to that of PANI.
Figure 4e shows the Nyqusit plots of pristine PANI, nano-Au@PANI-12, nano-Au@PANI-16, and Au@PANI-24, which exhibited similar shapes including a vertical line in low-frequency region and semi-circle in high-frequency region. The EIS spectra can be fitted with the equivalent circuit using ZSimpWin software as shown in Figure S1, and the fitted data for circuit elements are listed in Table S1. Rs represents the series resistance which consists of contact resistance, electrolyte resistance, and electrode resistance [37-39]. Cdl denoted capacitance representing the double layer capacitance arising from the storage of charges on the surface of electrode, and Rct was the resistance associated with the charge transfer process, which indicated the rate of the redox reaction taking place at the interface. And CF was a faradic capacitor. All of the nano-Au@PANI composites exhibited smaller value of Rs and Rct compared to that of pristine PANI due to the introduction of gold nanoparticles. In addition, the CF of pristine PANI (98.2 Fg -1) was smaller than nano-Au@PANI composite and the CF decreased from 209 to 189.8 F g -1 with the time prolonging. The results were consistent with the results from GCD data. Besides, the fitting data of Cd1 were 0.356, 0.152, 0.092 and 0.160 F/g for pristine PANI, nano-Au@PANI-12, nano-Au@PANI-16 and nano-Au@PANI-24, respectively. Specific capacitance (Cm) can be calculated via equation (5) [40,41]
Cm=1/2πf Im(Z)/m (eq.5)
Where f is frequency in Hz of the phase angle reaches -45 degrees, Im(Z) is the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
imaginary part of the impedance and m is the mass of active materials. The Cm values of the obtained products are listed in Table S1. Nano-Au@PANIs showed higher capacitances of 146.3, 160.9, and 129.5 F g-1 for nano-Au@PANI-12, nano-Au@PANI-16, and nano-Au@PANI-24, respectively, compared with pristine PANI of 59.7 F g-1.
The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and BET results are shown in Figure S2 and Table S2. Pristine PANI exhibited BET surface area of 22.1 m2/g and average pore size of 14.1 nm. However, BET surface area of 8.38 m2/g and average pore size of 12.0 nm was obtained for nano-Au@PANI-12; and BET surface area of 9.36 m2/g and pore size of 18.4 nm for nano-Au@PANI-24 were obtained. The nano-Au@PANI composites showed the surface area decline and variation of average pore size due to formation of nano-Au@PANI core shell structure. Moreover, the conductivity was measured by 4-point probes resistivity measurement system (RTS-9), and 5.3 S cm-1 for pristine PANI and 6.0, 6.3, and 5.6 S cm-1 for the samples of nano-Au@PANI-12, nano-Au@PANI-16, and nano-Au@PANI-24 were obtained, respectively. By contrast, nano-Au@PANI-16 showed the highest conductivity compared with the other products. These results agreed well with the smaller Rct from EIS results. Figure 4f is the cycle life of nano-Au@PANI-12 and the pristine PANI. After 2000 cycles, pristine PANI remained only 38.5 % of the initial specific capacitance, while nano-Au@PANI-12 showed 58.9 % of specific capacitance retention. For nano-Au@PANI-12, SC retention remained 66.6 % after 4000 cycles. The reason is because the nano-Au could provide the necessary electric transport channel during the charge/discharge process.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Besides reaction time, the monomer concentration also plays important role for the preparation of the core-shell nano-Au@PANI. Figure 5 shows the SC of nano-Au@PANIs prepared by different monomer concentration at different current density. It can be seen that, when the monomer concentration was 10 mM, the SC was higher than that of the others because high monomer concentration lead to rapid polymerization and aggregation of nanoparticles. In addition, too low monomer concentration (<10 mM) resulted in the failure of core-shell structure for
M
AN
US
CR
IP T
AC
CE
PT ED
nano-Au@PANI. When the current density increased from 0.5 A g-1 to 5 A g-1, the specific capacitance retentions were 87.7, 85.8, 73.9, and 77.7 % with increase of monomer concentration from 10 mM to 50 mM, respectively.
Figure 5 (a) SC of nano-Au@PANIs at different current density; and (b) SC of nano-Au@PANIs prepared by different monomer concentration (0.5 A g-1)
Figure 6 (a) CV curves and (b) Ragone plots of nano-Au@PANI//AC asymmetric supercapacitors. (inset: galvanostatic charge/discharge curves at different current density)
The prepared nano-Au@PANI was further assembled with AC to obtain
nano-Au@PANI//AC asymmetric supercapacitor. Figure 6a shows the CV curves of asymmetric supercapacitor at different scan rates from 5 mV s-1 to 50 mV s-1. It can be
seen that the quasi-rectangular shape for the variour scan rates replied the capacitors’
behaviors. The energy density and power density were further calculated, as shown in
Figure 6b. The energy density decreased gradually with increase of power density. This asymmetric supercapacitor exhibited a maximum energy density of 7.01 W h
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
kg-1 with the power density of 260 W kg-1; and the maximum power density of 4.2 kW kg-1 and energy density of 1.74 W h kg-1.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
Core-shell Nano-Au@PANI was synthesized by in-situ polymerization method on the
nano-Au surface; and based on the high conductivity core of nano-Au, the specific
capacitance and rate ability were enhanced compared to these of pristine PANI.
Furthermore, the cycle stability was visibly improved with 66.6 % retention of initial
specific capacitance. The asymmetric supercapacitor of nano-Au@PANI//AC was assembled, which showed a maximum energy density of 7.01 W h kg-1 and a maximum power density of 4.2 kW kg-1.

sections.heading: Acknowledges
sections.text: This work was partly supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (51203071, 51363014, and 51463012), China Postdoctoral Science Foundation (2014M552509, and 2015T81064), Natural Science Funds of the Gansu Province (2015GS05123), and the Program for Hongliu Distinguished Young Scholars in Lanzhou University of Technology (J201402).

sections.heading: Highlights
sections.text:
Nano-Au@PANI with an average diameter of 22.17 nm is fabricate via in-situ polymerization
Nano-Au@PANI shows enhanced electrochemical performance compared with pristine PANI
A asymmetric supercapacitor device of nano-Au@PANI//activated carbon is assembled
The maximum energy density and power density of 7.01 W h kg-1 and 4.2 kW kg-1 is obtained

referenceMentions.context: Electrochemical capacitors, also called ultrasupercapacitors or supercapacitors, as a new energy storage device, are applied in most fields such as portable electronics, hybrid electric vehicles, and so on, due to its good electrochemical performance of fast charging/discharging speed, high power density, and long cycle stability [1,2].

The curve of pristine PANI showed a peak at 1560 cm, which was assigned to ring C-C stretching in the semiquinonoid (SQ) and the peak at 1480 cm was due to B ring C-C stretching in NH-B-NH units (“B-band”) [32].

In the curve of nano-Au@PANI, the characterized peak of ~1630 cm was related to C=N vibrational stretching mode for the quinonoid units; and the peak at 1403 cm was ascribed to C-H scissoring vibrations [28].

~1175 cm can be assigned to the C-H in-plane deformation vibration of B rings, mixed with the contribution of asymmetric SO3 stretching in HSO4 - [32]; other peaks of ~1470 cm and ~1290 cm occurred a little offset compared to pristine PANI.

The strong peaks were owing to the redox transition of the PANI between a semiconducting state (leucoemeraldine form) and a conducting state (polaronic emeraldine form), and the weak peaks were attributed to the emeraldine-pernigraniline transformation [34, 35].

metadata.abstractText: With the aim of improving conductivity and shortening diffusion length, the conductive polymer polyaniline shell was grown on the surface of gold nanoparticles via in-situ polymerization, as confirmed by transmission electron microscopy, fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analyses. The core-shell nano-Au@PANI with an average diameter of 22.17 nm as well as the nano-Au with an average diameter of 18.52 nm was prepared. Electrochemical investigation by using CHI660E workstation exhibits that the prepared material has good electrochemical performance and the highest specific capacitance is up to 285.0 F g, far higher than that of the pristine PANI, 115.0 F g; after 4000 cycles, nano-Au@PANI displays better cycle stability compare with that of pristine PANI. Furthermore, nano-Au@PANI are combined with AC to fabricate the hybrid supercapacitor of nano-Au@PANI//AC, which shows a maximum energy density of 7.01 W h kg with the power density of 260 W kg; and the maximum power density of 4.2 kW kg and energy density of 1.74 W h kg.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
